channel.title: JaneBytes Cybersecurity Feed
channel.description: Summarized articles from top cybersecurity sources.

item.title: New Phishing Attack Poses as Zoom Meeting Invites to Steal Login Credentials
item.description: A newly identified phishing campaign targets users by masquerading as urgent Zoom meeting invitations from colleagues. The campaign leverages realism and psychological manipulation to steal login credentials, with a focus on customizing URLs using stolen data. Users are advised to verify authenticity and avoid interacting with suspicious links.

item.title: New Hannibal Stealer Uses Stealth and Obfuscation to Evade Detection
item.description: The Hannibal Stealer is a modular .NET info-stealer and credential harvester that demonstrates advanced stealth mechanisms and obfuscation techniques to bypass modern detection systems. It can extract sensitive data from browsers, cryptocurrency wallets, and popular applications, and features geofencing capabilities to avoid scrutiny in certain countries.

item.title: Chinese APT Hackers Target Organizations Using Korplug Loaders and Malicious USB Drives
item.description: Vulnerable Product: N/A; CVE(s): None; Summary: The article reports on advanced persistent threat (APT) groups with ties to China that have been targeting European governmental and industrial entities. These groups use sophisticated tactics and tools, including Korplug loaders, malicious USB drives, and backdoors, to infiltrate sensitive networks.

item.title: Cache Timing Techniques Used to Bypass Windows 11 KASLR and Reveal Kernel Base
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Windows 11; CVE(s): None; Summary: The article describes a cache timing side-channel attack that can circumvent Kernel Address Space Layout Randomization (KASLR) on fully updated Windows 11 PCs, exploiting speculative execution and processor cache behavior to infer the base address of ntoskrnl.exe. This attack requires no elevated privileges and has been successfully tested on Windows 11 version 10.0.26100.3775.

item.title: O2 UK patches bug leaking mobile user location from call metadata
item.description: Vulnerable Product: O2 UK (VoLTE and WiFi Calling technologies); CVE(s): None; Summary: A flaw in O2 UK's implementation of VoLTE and WiFi Calling technologies allows anyone to expose the general location of a person and other identifiers by calling the target, including IMSI, IMEI, and cell location data. The issue was resolved after being reported by security researcher Daniel Williams on March 26 and 27, 2025.

item.title: Hackers Exploit AutoIT Scripts to Deploy Malware Targeting Windows Systems
item.description: A sophisticated attack leveraging AutoIT scripting language was discovered, featuring a double-layered AutoIT script designed to deploy a potentially devastating payload. The attack involves the deployment of malicious DLLs, including AsyncRAT and PureHVNC, allowing attackers to maintain long-term access to infected systems.

item.title: Windows 10 emergency updates fix BitLocker recovery issues
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Windows; CVE(s): None; Summary: Windows 10 systems with Intel vPro processors (10th gen or later) and Intel Trusted Execution Technology (TXT) enabled may boot into BitLocker recovery after installing the May 2025 security updates. Installing KB5061768 emergency update or disabling TXT from BIOS can fix the issue.

item.title: Arla Foods confirms cyberattack disrupts production, causes delays
item.description: Arla Foods has been targeted by a cyberattack that disrupted its production operations at a facility in Germany, leading to product delivery delays or cancellations. The attack did not appear to involve data theft or encryption, and the type of attack and perpetrators remain unknown.

item.title: New Report Finds 67% of Organizations Experienced Cyber Attacks in the Last Year
item.description: A report by Hiscox Cyber Readiness Report 2024 shows a rising trend of cyberattacks across eight worldwide markets, with 67% of businesses experiencing attacks in the previous 12 months. The report highlights the impact of attacks on reputations, finances, and employee behavior, emphasizing the need for organizations to prioritize cybersecurity training and leadership.

item.title: Auth0-PHP Vulnerability Enables Unauthorized Access for Attackers
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Auth0-PHP SDK; CVE(s): None; Summary: The Auth0-PHP SDK versions 8.0.0-BETA1 and newer have a critical security vulnerability that allows unauthorized access to applications through brute force attacks on session cookie authentication tags, potentially leading to session hijacking and exploitation of sensitive information.

item.title: Active Exploitation of Ivanti EPMM Zero-Day Vulnerability in the Wild
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Ivanti Enterprise Mobility Management (EPMM); CVE(s): CVE-2025-4427, CVE-2025-4428; Summary: The zero-day vulnerability in Ivanti's EPMM platform can be chained with another vulnerability to achieve remote code execution, posing a significant threat to unpatched systems. Attackers have already attempted to exploit these security flaws, and many vulnerable instances remain exposed despite public disclosure.

item.title: Microsoft unveils Windows AI Foundry for AI-powered PC apps
item.description:
FYSA:
The article discusses Microsoft's new Windows AI Foundry, a tool that helps developers build, experiment, and reach users with AI experiences in their apps. The feature allows for the integration of various AI models, including open-source ones from Nvidia, and provides ready-to-use APIs for tasks such as text intelligence and image description. Additionally, it includes features like Foundry Local, which automatically matches models to a device's hardware, and developer tools like a command-line tool and SDK.

item.title: Hacker Arrested for Taking Over SEC Social Media to Spread False Bitcoin News
item.description: A 26-year-old man, Eric Council Jr., has been sentenced to 14 months in prison for orchestrating a sophisticated SIM swap attack that allowed him to hijack the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission's (SEC) social media account on X, formerly known as Twitter. The unauthorized access was used to post false information about Bitcoin ETF approvals, causing significant market volatility in cryptocurrency prices.

item.title: Investigating Cobalt Strike Beacons Using Shodan: A Researcher’s Guide
item.description: A security researcher has published a method for gathering threat intelligence on Cobalt Strike beacons using Shodan and PowerShell. The technique allows security professionals to collect configuration data from active Cobalt Strike servers, including beacon SpawnTo values and watermarks, which are critical for detection and attribution.

item.title: Volkswagen Car Hack Exposes Owner’s Personal Data and Service Records
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Volkswagen My Volkswagen app; CVE(s): None; Summary: The My Volkswagen app contains critical security flaws that allowed unauthorized access to vehicle information and personal data. A security researcher discovered the vulnerabilities by exploiting a fundamental authentication weakness and identified multiple API vulnerabilities, including the exposure of sensitive user information and internal system credentials.

item.title: Microsoft confirms new "Advanced" Settings for Windows 11
item.description: This article is not about a vulnerability, but rather discusses the new "Advanced Settings" feature in Windows 11. The feature allows users and developers to personalize their OS experience by customizing File Explorer and Virtual Machines settings.

item.title: Microsoft open-sources Windows Subsystem for Linux at Build 2025
item.description: Microsoft has open-sourced the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL), making its source code available on GitHub, except for a few components that are part of Windows. This move is expected to increase community involvement and contributions to the project, allowing developers to inspect the code, build it themselves, submit improvements, and understand how WSL works under the hood.

item.title: RVTools Official Site Hacked to Deliver Bumblebee Malware via Trojanized Installer
item.description: The official site for RVTools has been hacked to serve a compromised installer for the popular VMware environment reporting utility. Additionally, Procolored printers have been found to include malicious software with features such as collecting system information, logging keystrokes, and propagating via connected USB drives.

item.title: UK Legal Aid Agency confirms applicant data stolen in data breach
item.description: A data breach has occurred at the United Kingdom's Legal Aid Agency (LAA), where hackers stole a large amount of sensitive applicant data, including contact details, dates of birth, national ID numbers, criminal history, employment status, and financial information. The agency is advising all applicants to be vigilant for potential scam attempts targeting them.

item.title: Google Reveals Hackers Targeting US Following UK Retailer Attacks
item.description: UNC3944, a well-known hacker collective, has been identified by the Google Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG) as a persistent and dynamic cyberthreat. The group has evolved from initial SIM swap operations to ransomware and data theft extortion tactics, with a focus on large enterprises in English-speaking countries. Their modus operandi relies heavily on sophisticated social engineering, and they have orchestrated sector-specific waves of attacks, including financial services, food services, and retail sectors.

item.title: Skitnet Malware Employs Stealth Techniques to Execute Payload and Maintain Persistence Techniques
item.description: Skitnet (Bossnet) is a highly sophisticated multi-stage malware developed by the threat group LARVA-306. It features advanced stealth techniques and evasion methods to execute its malicious payload, maintain persistent access on infected systems, and evade detection by security defenses.

item.title: Ransomware Gangs Use Skitnet Malware for Stealthy Data Theft and Remote Access
item.description: Skitnet is a multi-stage malware used by ransomware actors for post-exploitation efforts, stealing sensitive data and establishing remote control over compromised hosts. It uses programming languages like Rust and Nim to evade detection, and incorporates persistence mechanisms, remote access tools, commands for data exfiltration, and download of additional payloads.

item.title: Mozilla fixes Firefox zero-days exploited at hacking contest
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Mozilla Firefox; CVE(s): CVE-2025-4918, CVE-2025-4919; Summary: Two Firefox zero-day vulnerabilities were demonstrated at the Pwn2Own Berlin 2025 hacking competition. The flaws, tracked under CVE-2025-4918 and CVE-2025-4919, are an out-of-bounds read/write issue in the JavaScript engine and a flaw allowing attackers to perform out-of-bounds reads/writes on a JavaScript object.

item.title: Hackers earn $1,078,750 for 28 zero-days at Pwn2Own Berlin
item.description: The article reports on the Pwn2Own Berlin 2025 hacking competition, where security researchers exploited 29 zero-day vulnerabilities and earned $1,078,750 in cash awards. No specific vulnerability details are provided.

item.title: CISA Adds Six Known Exploited Vulnerabilities to Catalog
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM), MDaemon Email Server, Srimax Output Messenger, Synacor Zimbra Collaboration Suite (ZCS), ZKTeco BioTime; CVE(s): CVE-2025-4427, CVE-2025-4428, CVE-2024-11182, CVE-2025-27920, CVE-2024-27443, CVE-2023-38950; Summary: Six new vulnerabilities have been added to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog due to evidence of active exploitation. These vulnerabilities affect Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile, MDaemon Email Server, Srimax Output Messenger, Synacor Zimbra Collaboration Suite (ZCS), and ZKTeco BioTime, and are frequent attack vectors for malicious cyber actors, posing significant risks to the federal enterprise.

item.title: Why CTEM is the Winning Bet for CISOs in 2025
item.description: The article discusses the concept of Continuous Threat Exposure Management (CTEM), which solidifies its role as a strategic enabler for Chief Information Security Officers (CISOs). CTEM integrates Adversarial Exposure Validation (AEV) and Exposure Assessment Platforms (EAP) to empower CISOs to adopt a continuous, adaptive model that keeps pace with attacker techniques and the evolving threat landscape.

item.title: Firefox Patches 2 Zero-Days Exploited at Pwn2Own Berlin with $100K in Rewards
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Mozilla Firefox; CVE(s): CVE-2025-4918, CVE-2025-4919; Summary: Two critical security flaws in Firefox browser could allow an attacker to perform out-of-bounds read or write, potentially accessing sensitive data or executing code. The vulnerabilities affect all versions of Firefox before 138.0.4 and certain ESR versions.

item.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Zero-Day Exploits, Insider Threats, APT Targeting, Botnets and More
item.description:
The article discusses various cybersecurity-related topics, including:
1. A Nomad Bridge crypto hack and its alleged perpetrator, Alexander Gurevich. 2. Rogue communication devices found in some Chinese-made solar power inverters that could potentially allow remote control of energy infrastructure. 3. Using V8 browser exploits to bypass Windows Defender Application Control (WDAC). 4. Hidden threats in files users trust too much, such as .desktop files running hidden shell commands or .lnk files launching PowerShell or remote scripts. 5. Cybersecurity tools and webinars for improving security practices.
No specific software or hardware vulnerabilities are discussed in this article.

item.title: Hackers Exploit RVTools to Deploy Bumblebee Malware on Windows Systems
item.description: Vulnerable Product: RVTools; CVE(s): None; Summary: The RVTools installer was compromised with a custom variant of the Bumblebee loader malware, which served as an initial access vector for cyber campaigns. The vulnerability allowed attackers to exploit trust in the software supply chain and deploy malicious payloads.

item.title: Confluence Servers Under Attack: Hackers Leverage Vulnerability for RDP Access and Remote Code Execution
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Atlassian Confluence; CVE(s): CVE-2023-22527; Summary: A template injection flaw in unpatched Atlassian Confluence servers exposed to the internet allowed threat actors to exploit remote code execution (RCE), gaining initial access and establishing a foothold within targeted networks. The vulnerability was exploited through a meticulously planned intrusion, leading to data encryption and lateral movement using various tools and tactics.

item.title: New ModiLoader Malware Campaign Targets Windows PCs, Harvesting User Credentials
item.description: The article describes a malicious campaign distributing ModiLoader (DBatLoader) malware through phishing emails. The malware uses a multi-stage infection process to deploy SnakeKeylogger, an infostealer malware that steals sensitive data and transmits it to a Telegram bot. The infection process involves various evasion tactics, including DLL side-loading and manipulation of Windows Defender exclusion paths, making detection challenging for standard antivirus solutions.

item.title: Health Care Data Breach Costs BreachForums Admin $700,000 Fine
item.description: Conor Brian Fitzpatrick, a former administrator of the cybercrime forum Breachforums, will forfeit approximately $700,000 to settle a civil lawsuit related to a healthcare data breach. This marks a rare instance where a cybercriminal's assets directly compensate victims of a data breach. The case highlights connections between cybercriminal communities and more serious offenses, such as possession of child sexual abuse material (CSAM).

item.title: Critical Firefox 0-Day Flaws Allow Remote Code Execution
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Mozilla Firefox; CVE(s): CVE-2025-4918, CVE-2025-4919; Summary: Two critical 0-day vulnerabilities in Firefox allow remote attackers to execute malicious code. The flaws, tracked as CVE-2025-4918 and CVE-2025-4919, arise from out-of-bounds access conditions when resolving Promise objects or handling linear sums in array operations, allowing data leakage, browser crashes, or arbitrary code execution under the context of the browser.

item.title: CISA to Stop Publishing Cybersecurity Alerts and Advisories on Webpages
item.description: CISA has announced changes to its communication strategy for cybersecurity updates and guidance, shifting away from listing advisories on its webpage to focus on direct communication channels. The change was temporarily paused after community feedback, with the agency reassessing its approach to information sharing.

item.title: Pwn2Own Day 3: Zero-Day Exploits Windows 11, VMware ESXi, and Firefox
item.description: The Pwn2Own Berlin 2025 competition showcased impressive technological achievements, demonstrating critical zero-day vulnerabilities in high-profile targets like Windows 11, VMware ESXi, and Mozilla Firefox. The event's prize pool reached $1,078,750, highlighting the growing importance of security research in an increasingly connected world.

item.title: GNU C(glibc) Vulnerability Let Attackers Execute Arbitrary Code on Millions of Linux Systems
item.description: Vulnerable Product: GNU C Library (glibc); CVE(s): CVE-2025-4802; Summary: A vulnerability in the glibc library allows attackers to execute malicious code with elevated privileges by placing a malicious shared library in a location specified by the LD_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable. The flaw affects statically linked setuid binaries that incorrectly search library paths, potentially allowing local attackers to elevate their privileges.

item.title: Exploiting dMSA for Advanced Active Directory Persistence
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Windows Server 2025; CVE(s): None; Summary: Delegated Managed Service Accounts (dMSAs) in Windows Server 2025 can be manipulated by attackers with specific permissions to establish persistent access. Attackers can exploit Access Control List (ACL) inheritance to gain full visibility and control over dMSA objects, achieving persistence through creating additional dMSAs or adding unauthorized entities to the PrincipalAllowedToRetrieveManagedPassword attribute.

item.title: New 'Defendnot' tool tricks Windows into disabling Microsoft Defender
item.description: Vulnerable Product: No specific product mentioned; Defendnot is the tool being discussed; CVE(s): None; Summary: The Defendnot tool can disable Microsoft Defender on Windows devices by registering a fake antivirus product, using an undocumented Windows Security Center API. This allows the tool to bypass Windows' safeguards and register the dummy antivirus, effectively disabling real-time protection for the device.

item.title: VMware ESXi, Firefox, Red Hat Linux & SharePoint Hacked – Pwn2Own Day 2
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: Oracle VirtualBox; CVE(s): None; Summary: Viettel Cyber Security used an OOB Write for a Guest-to-Host escape on Oracle VirtualBox, earning $40,000 and 4 Master of Pwn points.
FYSA: The competition has awarded a cumulative total of $695,000 with participants revealing 20 unique zero-day vulnerabilities thus far.

item.title: Microsoft confirms May Windows 10 updates trigger BitLocker recovery
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Windows 10; CVE(s): None; Summary: Some Windows 10 and Windows 10 Enterprise LTSC 2021 systems will boot into BitLocker recovery after installing the May 2025 security updates. This issue may trigger an Automatic Repair, which requires input of a BitLocker recovery key to initiate the repair.

item.title: Critical WordPress Plugin Flaw Puts Over 10,000 Sites of Cyberattack
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Eventin plugin for WordPress; CVE(s): None; Summary: The Eventin plugin allows unauthenticated users to gain administrative access to affected sites due to a lack of proper permission checks in the /wp-json/eventin/v2/speakers/import REST API endpoint. This vulnerability can be exploited by uploading a CSV file containing user details, including the desired role set to administrator.

item.title: Sophisticated NPM Attack Leverages Google Calendar2 for Advanced Communication
item.description: Vulnerable Product: os-info-checker-es6; CVE(s): None; Summary: A sophisticated malware campaign was embedded within the npm package os-info-checker-es6, which evolved from gathering basic OS information to a complex threat using platform-specific compiled Node.js modules and obfuscation techniques. The malware employed steganography, Unicode-based hiding of malicious payloads, and a command-and-control mechanism utilizing Google Calendar short links.

item.title: New Ransomware Attack Targets Elon Musk Supporters Using PowerShell to Deploy Payloads
item.description: A newly identified ransomware campaign targets supporters of Elon Musk through a sophisticated phishing-based attack. The attack begins with a deceptive PDF document, which leads to the download of malicious ZIP files hosted on Netlify. The infection chain involves multi-stage PowerShell scripts and executables designed to compromise the target system, ultimately deploying a variant of the Fog ransomware for financial gain.

item.title: Printer Company Distributes Malicious Drivers Infected with XRed Malware
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Procolored; CVE(s): None; Summary: Procolored's software drivers contained malicious code, including the XRed backdoor malware and SnipVex virus. The XRed backdoor facilitated keylogging, file downloads, screenshots, and remote command execution, while SnipVex posed a persistent threat by targeting .exe files and replacing Bitcoin addresses in the clipboard to divert transactions.

item.title: Chinese Agent Impersonate as Stanford Student For Intelligence Gathering
item.description: A Chinese intelligence operative posing as a Stanford University student has been uncovered, targeting students conducting China-related research. The agent used the alias "Charles Chen" and employed a "crowdsourced approach" to gather sensitive information, including using civilians unaffiliated with intelligence agencies to collect data. This case highlights concerns about Chinese intelligence activities at American universities and the need for increased awareness.

item.title: Israel arrests new suspect behind Nomad Bridge $190M crypto hack
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Nomad bridge smart-contract; CVE(s): None; Summary: The Nomad bridge smart-contract introduced a critical vulnerability in its Replica smart contract, allowing hackers to siphon over $190 million worth of assets. The flaw allowed any message with a correct root hash to be accepted, even if the underlying proof was invalid.

item.title: ChatGPT rolls out Codex, an AI tool for software programming
item.description: The article discusses OpenAI's new AI agent, Codex, which automates and delegates programming tasks for software engineers. Codex can write new code, propose pull requests, and run each task in its own sandbox, making developers more productive with AI.

item.title: Hackers exploit VMware ESXi, Microsoft SharePoint zero-days at Pwn2Own
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Multiple; CVE(s): None; Summary: Competitors successfully exploited zero-day bugs in multiple products, including Microsoft SharePoint, VMware ESXi, Oracle VirtualBox, Red Hat Enterprise Linux, and Mozilla Firefox, earning a total of $695,000 over the first two days of the contest.

item.title: Printer maker Procolored offered malware-laced drivers for months
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Procolored printers; CVE(s): None; Summary: The official software supplied with Procolored printers included a remote access trojan (XRedRAT) and a cryptocurrency stealer (SnipVex) for at least six months. These malware were delivered through the companion software and drivers for Procolored UV printer models F8, F13, F13 Pro, V6, V11 Pro, and VF13 Pro.

item.title: Ransomware gangs increasingly use Skitnet post-exploitation malware
item.description: Skitnet ("Bossnet") is a new malware used by ransomware gangs for post-exploitation activities. It uses a Rust-based loader to decrypt a Nim binary and establish a DNS-based reverse shell for communication with the command and control server. The malware supports various commands, including persistence, screenshot capture, remote access tool installation, and antivirus enumeration.
